text: Deli Hasan (died 1605) was an Ottoman military commander who after leading a rebellion in Anatolia became governor of Bosnia and then of Temeşvar. After the death of his brother, a leading figure in the Celali rebellions, Deli Hasan took command of a group of rebels,Mustafa Naima, Annals of the Turkish Empire from 1591 to 1659, translated by Charles Fraser, vol. 1 (London, 1832), p. 201. soon numbered in the thousands, and established his power in Afyonkarahisar. He looted Kütahya and exacted tribute from Ankara.Karen Barkey, Bandits and Bureaucrats: The Ottoman Route to State Centralization (Cornell University Press, 1994), p. 153. His success led to the Ottoman court bribing him back to loyalty with the rank of pasha and appointment as governor in Bosnia, where his followers were employed in the service of the state.Karen Barkey, Bandits and Bureaucrats: The Ottoman Route to State Centralization (Cornell University Press, 1994), pp. 206-7. He crossed into Europe on 2 April 1603, with an army numbering 10,000 men, and in May was taking part in the unsuccessful siege of Pest.Joseph von Hammer-Purgstall, Geschichte des osmanischen Reiches, vol. 2, 1520–1623 (Pest, 1840), pp. 662-3. His government in Bosnia was short and turbulent. In 1604 he was transferred to Temeşvar.William J. Griswold, The Great Anatolian Rebellion, 1000-1020/1591-1611 (1983) . The following year he fled to Belgrade after an attempt on his life, but was imprisoned there and executed.Mustafa Naima, Annals of the Turkish Empire from 1591 to 1659, translated by Charles Fraser, vol. 1 (London, 1832), p. 315. ==References== Category:Year of birth unknown Category:1605 deaths Category:People of the Long Turkish War Category:17th- century Ottoman military personnel Category:17th-century executions by the Ottoman Empire Category:Rebellions against the Ottoman Empire Category:Ottoman governors of Bosnia Category:Pashas
